section.p: The Management Console is mainly modified in Settings Console . Settings are saved as variables which you can subsequently deployed in HTML pages using the Embedded JavaScript (EJS) templating engine.

dlentry.dd: Overrides all occurrences of the version number
Sets the default locale of the console if the user's current locale is not recognized. Currently, only the en and de localizations are available.

section.title: Client
section.p: Sets the CLI client version number and the paths or URLs to the downloadable archives for each platform.

note.p: Local paths are relative to the /home// directory (for the router node, see Renaming the Client). However, you can also use HTTP URLs for externally-hosted files.

section.p: The CLI client executables served from the VM are the latest version available at the time of a VM release. However, updated clients may become available between releases. The current release of the CLI client is always available for download.

dlentry.dd: Sets the favicon that is displayed in the browser (a 32×32 px .png file is recommended)
Sets the logo image that is displayed in the header (size can vary, but images larger than 50 px vertically require a stylesheet adjustment)
Sets the logo image that is displayed to use in the footer (size can vary, but images larger than 40 px vertically require a stylesheet adjustment)
Sets the background color of the console

section.title: Welcome Page
section.p: Sets the HTML/EJS that is displayed in the Welcome view. You can use the settings variables and the username (current user) variable via EJS. However, plain HTML will work for simple use cases.

section.title: Support Page
section.p: Sets the HTML/EJS that is displayed in the Support view. You can use the settings variables and the support_email variable (see Settings Controller ).

section.title: Eula Content
section.p: Sets the HTML/EJS that is displayed in the EULA overlay. You can use the settings variables.

section.title: Custom Stylesheet
section.p: Defines the CSS that will be applied after the default stylesheet loads, and overrides or replaces any style. You can use a custom stylesheet to change the layout and color of any element in the Management Console. You can use a web development tool such as Firebug or Chrome DevTools to inspect elements and find the relevant styles.
